intro: Tetrathylacium macrophyllum, commonly known as the broadleaf tetrathylacium, is a flowering plant native to the Pacific Northwest of North America. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its compound leaves and small, yellowish flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forests and stream banks. Its botanical features include a slender stem, alternate leaves with a distinctive pinnate structure, and a short flowering period in early summer. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
